body.p:
To His Excellency James F. Robinson
Governor of the State of Kentucky.

Your petitioners, Moses Block, and Fanny Block, citizens of this State, residing in the City of Louisville, would respectfully state that upon the 6th day of July 1863, They were tried upon an Indictment for an Assault & Battery, in the Louisville City Court, and by a verdict of a jury fined as follows Moses Block $10000 & Fanny Block $5000 A certified copy of the Judgment rendered in pursuance of said verdict, is made a part of this petition.

They state that they are man & wife, that they and the prosecuting witness are Jews, that they sented to the prosecuting witness, & to her family, a part of the building in which they reside, that prior to the alledged asault, they notified prosecuting witness to lease and said notice having expired on Sunday prior to removal of said tenants, the prosecuting witness. Mrs Moses Dinkelsfiel, commenced to clean and scrub a lot of old dry goods boxes, in the back yard of said residence, wasting much of the cistern water on said premises, and so wasting said water, as to cause the back yard to become sloppy, wet, and
very uncomfortable. Your petitioner Moses Block after requesting said Mrs Dinkelsfiel to cease her work, without avail, proceded to remove the handle from the cistern pump. whereupon she said Mrs Dinkelsfiel, procured a bucket and safe, and having forced at the boards nailed upon the top of the cistern, commenced to draw water from the said cistern, so as to continue and increase said nuisance.

Your petitioner Moses Block, then attempted to take the bucket from the said Mrs Dinkelsfiel, when a contest ensued, and during the same your petitioner Fanny Block, undertook to assist her husband the sd Moses Block, in obtaining said bucket.

In this scuffle your Petitioner Moses Block, had his shirt, and vest torn off. Fanny Block had her hair pulled down & ^received^ a blow upon the face, and Mrs Dinkelsfiel received an accidental but slight injury ^also^ upon the face.

Said injury to Mrs Dinkelsfiel, the prosecuting witness was neither permanent serious or painfull, and the affair was brought to Court, more out of revenge &
malice than in furtherance of Justice. Your petitioners being without witnesses and the said Mrs Dinkelsfiel, prosecuting, and so garbling her statements as to prejudice the jury, the trial resulted as above set forth.
Your Petitioners being without proof, did not apply for a new trial.

They would further state that Moses Block is 52. years of age, that Fanny Block is 46. years of age, that this is the first complaint ever brought against them in court, that that they are quiet law abiding citizens; are in very moderate circumstances, with a family dependent upon them, that the payment of said sum of $150.00 would cause them & their family much suffering & distress; that great injustice was done your petitioners by the amount of said fine, and they therefore appeal to your Excellency to interpose and discharge them so far as it may be in your power, from said injustice and loss. by a remission of said fine. and this as in duty bound they will ever pray.

State of Kentucky
Jefferson County } Sct.

Moses Block & Fanny Block say that the
statements in the foregoing petition are true

Moses Block.
Fanny ^her X mark^ Block
Subscribed & sworn to before me by Moses & Fanny Block, this 16th day of July 1863.
Wm Minx Jr N. P. J. C,
Recd Louisville Ky July 20th 1863 from Moses Block & Wife Sixty 60/100 Dollars in full of cost and Fees in fifa which issued against them the above date from the city court of Louisville
W. R. Hydes M. C. C. L.

$60,,60/100
Respectfully recommend, that fifty dollars of the aforementioned fine be remitted

I unite with the city attorney. I know Mr Block who is a very quiet orderly & good citizen, verry many of the citizens have asked a remission of the whole fine & his Excellency will decide from the circumstances stated, how far he will Exercise Executive clemency
Geo W Johnston J. c c. L.
